prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: SigmaOri Targets -- B6 CO, 13CO, C18O (all J=2-1) +cont.
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note:
We propose for interferometric observations with ALMA at high sensitivity and angular resolution in order to study molecular outflow activity for six proto-brown dwarf (proto-BD) candidates.
We will observe the transitions of CO and 13CO (in the J=2-1 transition) simultaneously with ALMA in opposite sidebands, in Band 6. The C18O (J=2-1) line can also be observed in conjunction with these lines.
The proposed CO maps will be important to study the kinematics and dynamics of the outflows. The C18O line observed in bonus will be valuable to investigate the kinematics and dynamical structure in proto-BD envelopes/disks. The continuum window has been included to extend the wavelength coverage for the proto-BD SEDs, and will complement the already available 850mu continuum observations.
We have created three science goals, since all of our targets are not within 10 degrees of each other. The objectives and technical setup for each science goal are the same.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: We have set the bandwidth for all spectral lines to 117MHz. For 960 channels per bandwidth (spectral averaging =4), this provides a spectral resolution of ~121 kHz or ~0.16 km/s. From line radiative tranfer modeling, the expected line widths for our targets are ~1-2 km/s, and therefore should be resolved with this setup.

We will use the C36-2 configuration that provides an angular resolution of 0.8" and a maximum recoverable scale of 11". The position velocity diagrams in the near-infrared [FeII] lines for the proto-BD targets indicate compact jets with small spatial scales of ~2". Therefore, with a 0.8" resolution, we should be able to resolve the outflow lobes. The maximum recoverable scale of 11" with C36-2 is adequate to recover the full spatial scale of ~4" expected for the outflows, and will also allow us to study how the outflow structure and width change as we move farther out spatially from the driving source. We can probe any episodic events that would produce knots and a bow-shock morphology.
We have not selected the higher resolution option of C36-3 (0.5"), since that would double the total observing time.

We have used the '6b' spectral setup listed in Table 6.1 in the ALMA Technical Handbook. In this setup, the upper sideband consists of the 12CO(2-1) line at 230.5 GHz and a continuum window at 231.9 GHz in basebands 1 and 2, respectively. The lower sideband consists of the C18O(2-1) at 219.5 GHz and 13CO(2-1) lines at 220.4 GHz in basebands 3 and 4, respectively. The LO1 is at 225.5 GHz. The continuum window has been included to extend the wavelength coverage for the proto-brown dwarf (proto-BD) spectral energy distributions, and will complement the already available JCMT/SCUBA-2 870mu continuum observations.
Our main line of interest is the 12CO (2-1) transition. This is set as the representative frequency. We have conducted line radiative transfer modeling for our proto-BD targets, using the RADMC-3D models. The predicted 12CO peak line intensity from line modeling is in the range of ~30-80 mJy. The lowest peak intensity is for the sigma Orionis targets, which are located at the farthest distance (~350pc) than the other targets in the sample. We have set the desired sensitivity per pointing to 5 mJy (~0.17 K), so that we can obtain at least a S/N~5 even for the weakest predicted line intensity. We have set the bandwidth to ~117.2 MHz for all spectral lines, which provides a resolution of ~121 kHz, or a smoothed resolution of ~0.16 km/s. This is adequate to resolve the 12CO lines for our targets, with expected line widths of ~1-2 km/s. Since this is our desired spectral resolution, we have used the finest resolution option of ~121 kHz for estimating the line sensitivity.
Our estimates on the peak CO (2-1) line intensities derived from models are similar to the CO line intensity of ~1-3 K measured for the previously known proto-BD SMM2E (Palau et al. 2014). The SMA observations for this source in the CO (2-1) transition were obtained at a lower angular resolution of ~3", and have a rms noise of ~0.3 K, with a resolution of ~1 km/s. The observed CO(2-1) line width for SMM2E is ~4 km/s. Our technical setup is at a higher line sensitivity and spectral resolution, and should be able to detect the narrower lines expected for our targets. The total time estimated using ALMA OT for this science goal, including calibration and overheads, is ~3.28 hour.
We note that we cannot observe at the lower frequencies in Band 3 despite of the higher line sensitivity, since the dust continuum emission is an order of magnitude stronger at 1mm than at 3mm. The expected continuum fluxes at 3mm obtained from extrapolating the radiative transfer model fits for the proto-BDs are <0.1 mJy, and would therefore require a much longer time to reach the desired sensitivity.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: Molecular outflows can be a useful tool to understand the physical processes during the early Class 0/I evolutionary stages of star formation. While molecular outflow activity has been extensively studied in protostars, there are to date only two known cases among Class 0/I sub-stellar mass objects (M<0.08 Msun), or proto-brown dwarfs (proto-BDs). We have uncovered six Class I proto-BDs that exhibit prominent emission in the outflow-associated [FeII] lines in the near-infrared, with mass outflow rates consistent with previously known proto-BDs. Spectro-astrometric analysis indicates compact jets for these sources, with small spatial scales of ~2. We propose for high-sensitivity observations with ALMA in the CO (2-1) and 13CO (2-1) lines to study the physical properties of molecular outflows for these new proto-BDs. High angular resolution afforded by ALMA will be essential to resolve the compact outflows. If brown dwarfs form like stars, we would expect the outflow physical properties for proto-BDs to fit into the previously established correlations for protostars. Observations of the bonus C18O line will be highly valuable to investigate the structure in proto-BD envelopes/disks.

prp:CoInvestigator.prp:organisation: School of Physics, Astronomy and Mathematics, Hertfordshire, University of
